Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: An easygoing regular politely asks for a tiny adjustment to their fringe.
Expectation2: Dress modestly according to Islamic guidelines.
Situation2: They are about to enter the main prayer hall for Friday congregational worship.
Story: I was just about to leave the salon for Friday prayers, my scarf pinned neatly and my abaya buttoned up, when Mrs. Lee, my regular, caught my arm. “Could you just trim this bit of fringe? It’s poking my eye,” she said, smiling apologetically. I glanced at the clock—if I hurried, I’d just make it to the mosque in time. But I’d have to take off my abaya and scarf to work, as always, since hairdressing means leaning in close, and stray hairs cling to everything. I could see Mrs. Lee’s trust in her eyes; she always left happy, and I prided myself on that. But the thought of rushing to the mosque afterward, hair clinging to my clothes, maybe not fully covered, made my stomach twist. I wanted to be there, presentable and clean, for the prayer. My hands hovered over my scarf, torn between my client’s gentle request and my own need to honor my faith.
